Drosophila mauritiana is a species of fruit fly that belongs to the Drosophila melanogaster species group. It is endemic to the island of Mauritius, located in the Indian Ocean.

Drosophila mauritiana is a small, winged insect with a body length of approximately 2-3 millimeters. It has a characteristic yellowish-brown color with dark bands on its abdomen. The species exhibits sexual dimorphism, with males being slightly larger than females and having distinctive sex combs on their forelegs.

Drosophila mauritiana is an important model organism in evolutionary and genetic research due to its relatively small genome size and short generation time. It has been extensively studied to understand the processes of speciation, genetic variation, and the evolution of reproductive isolation mechanisms.

Ecologically, the species plays a role in the decomposition of organic matter, particularly overripe or decaying fruits, as it feeds on the yeasts and bacteria present in these substrates. Drosophila mauritiana is also an important component of the food web, serving as a prey item for various predators in its native ecosystem.
